newsitem.title: UK: BP Amethyst gas field back up after month closure.
newsitem.headline: BP Amethyst gas field back up after month closure.

text.p: The Amethyst gas field in the North Sea's southern gas basin off eastern England resumed production on Tuesday after a one month shutdown, operator British Petroleum Co Plc said on Tuesday.

Production at Amethyst, which has a capacity of around 300 million cubic feet per day (MMcfd), was shut off on Sept 13 when an anchor from a tanker ruptured the methanol line and main power line to the platforms.
On Tuesday, output was 180 MMcfd, its full nomination for the day to sole purchaser British Gas Plc, a BP spokesman said.
The shutdown was longer than the 10-14 days initially anticipated.
"The methanol line needed lengthy repairs. We were making sure we did it right and safely," the spokesman said.
Repairs to the power cable have not yet been completed and the field is running off generators at the platforms.
No damage was found to the main 30-inch gas export line after inspection by divers.
Amethyst gas is landed at the British Gas Rough terminal at Easington in Humberside.
